title: One man shares his love for all things Comme des Garçons
text:
Launched in 1969, Comme des Garçons was unlike anything else. The clothing was deliberately voluminous and oversized, playing with proportion to subvert the female form and ideas of beauty. For Kawakubo, fashion was not about making the body look good; it was about using the body as a canvas for her “wearable abstractions”, as she once put it. Opening a boutique in Paris in 1981, she quickly gained notoriety for her anarchic chic.

Rei Kawakubo in 2016, wearing a Comme des Garçons leather jacket. Getty

After his failed interview, Taka went on to work in various boutiques across Tokyo and, in 1986, began collecting Comme.

“At the start I was just buying things to wear,” he says, noting that he took advantage of Kawakubo’s “shapeless, baggy, black, genderless” pieces. But in 1986, when her womenswear became more overtly feminine – with bias-cut dresses, for example – he turned his sights to collecting.

“I just had to have them. Something pushed me and I… I just had to have them.”

Takahashi has about 100 Comme garments from almost every collection Kawakubo has shown. Eugene Hyland

As his collection grew, he would invite his female friends around for dress-up parties. “I wanted to see them on! And they’re too tight for me. I wanted to see them, not on a mannequin but on a woman. You want to see the way the dress moves.”

If someone can be inspired by the collection to create something new and beautiful, then I would be very happy. — Takamasa Takahashi

These days, Taka has about 100 Comme pieces from almost every collection Kawakubo has presented. “I wasn’t too keen on the 2D collection from 2012. But of course I still bought a piece,” he says, laughing.

This number does not include the items he has donated to the NGV and Canberra’s National Gallery of Australia, of which he says he’s lost count. He began donating them in 2005 after moving with long-time partner David Tune to the Gold Coast and noticing they were attracting mould in the humidity.

Advertisement

Moving to Australia in 1989 made collecting Comme more difficult. He eventually found it stocked by the boutiques Trellini in Melbourne and Five Way Fusion in Sydney – “but, you know, at three times the Japanese price”. So he enlisted a friend employed by the brand in Japan to hold pieces aside until other friends could then send them over. “They all knew the love I had for Comme des Garçons. It was very kind of them.”

Top and skirt (1996) from the Body Meets Dress – Dress Meets Body collection, spring/summer 1997.

Everything changed when eBay launched. “Then,” he says, gesturing with his hands, “boom!” When I ask what he thinks of the Melbourne Comme store, he is thrown; he didn’t know there was one. “Oh my God!” he exclaims. “That is great news.”

As for financing all this high fashion – ready-to-wear pieces retail around the $1500 mark – Taka insists he is not rich but that “fashion was everything to me. All of my pay … sort of just went to Comme. I needed to buy [the pieces]. I don’t know what the drive was, but I really wanted them. You know, one season ends and then you can’t get it any more. So it was important for me to have at least a few pieces from each season.”

I only wear Comme in Melbourne, and in Melbourne I only wear Comme. — Takamasa Takahashi

Though Comme is sometimes criticised for being unwearable, Taka says this is missing the point. “It’s not about wearability. It’s about the challenge of creativity, it’s about defining what is beautiful. And [Kawakubo] managed every season to create something completely different.”

Recently, Taka hasn’t felt overly compelled to buy new pieces, noting that Kawakubo’s work seems to be catering to younger customers. “To me, it’s not the Comme des Garçons I used to know. But probably she’s targeting a new generation, a new market. To me, people of my generation, we know what CDG is really about, and I don’t see it these days.”

"All of my pay … sort of just went to Comme," Takahasi recalls. Eugene Hyland

With the NGV exhibition opening next month, Taka has been reflecting on his collection. “Back in the ’80s, I just loved Comme des Garçons. I felt this sort of … quiet excitement when I saw the clothes,” he says. “Recently I've been wondering why I started.

“I wanted to do something with the clothes, keep them, but I didn’t know why. But I think donating them to the NGV has been the right thing. Because they can preserve them for future generations, and study them, and keep them for young fashion students. And if someone can be inspired by the collection to create something new and beautiful, then I would be very happy.”

Jacket and blouse (2005), Broken Bride collection, autumn/winter 2005-2006.

The exhibition will feature about 60 pieces, along with footage of Kawakubo’s shows. Taka – who will of course wear Comme to the opening (“I only wear Comme in Melbourne, and in Melbourne I only wear Comme”) – was blown away that Kawakubo’s team replied to the NGV curators, given her reputation as publicity-averse.

“I was so surprised she even got back to them,” he says. “But you know, to me, that’s part of her appeal. To me, Rei is very Japanese, she doesn’t show her emotion much. I think there is a lot of power in that.

“She’s always said that hard work says everything. I think that’s the perfect answer.”

NEED TO KNOW

Collecting Comme at the NGV, November 1 to March 2020.
description: Takamasa Takahashi can barely explain his compulsion to collect the avant-garde Japanese label – but he’s delighted the work is going on display at the NGV.
